Comment: As a man of honor, Philidor accepts.
A sure way to prevent a Black counterattack of ...Q-R5 ch, always a danger in the King's Gambit.
Naturally, Atwood goes after the weakness at KB7.
Philidor hastens to begin his own development and consolidate his position.
Adding a defender to the KB2 square.
I must be missing something here. Why is 9 PxQ a bad move? I can't imagine Atwood overlooking it, or Philidor missing it when he played his previous move.
Having forced Atwood's King to move, the Queen retreats.
Down a piece and a Pawn, Atwood must attack.
Philidor cuts him off at the pass.
Enabling the QB to move folowed by O-O-O. With his attack gone and down a piece without compensation, Atwood resigns.
